text.title: part0_Wikinews interviews Australian Glider Amanda Carter

head: Wikinews interviews Australian Glider Amanda Carter

figure.caption: Listen to the interview Image: Hawkeye7.

p: Melbourne, Australia â€” Monday, following her return from London, Wikinews talked with Amanda Carter, the longest-serving member of Australia's national wheelchair basketball team (the Gliders).
((Wikinews)) You're Amanda Carter!
((WN)) And, where were you born?

p.p: Amanda Carter: I was born in Melbourne.

p: ((WN)) It says here that you spent your childhood living in Banyule?

p.p: Amanda Carter: City of Banyule, but I was West Heidelberg.

p: ((WN)) Okay. And you used to play netball when you were young?
((WN)) And you're an occupational therapist, and you have a son called Alex?

p.p: Amanda Carter: Yes. It says "occupational therapist" on the door even. And I do have a son called Alex. Which is him there [pointing to his picture].

p: ((WN)) Any more children?

p.p: Amanda Carter: No, just the one.

p: ((WN)) You began playing basketball in 1991.
((WN)) And that you're a guard.
((WN)) And that you are a one point player.
((WN)) And you used to be a two point player?

p.p: Amanda Carter: I used to be a two point player.

p: ((WN)) When were you first selected for the national team?
((WN)) And that was for Barcelona?

p.p: Amanda Carter: It was for a tournament prior to then. Australia had to qualify at a pre-Paralympic tournament in England in about April of 1992 and I was selected for that. And that was my first trip overseas with the Gliders.

p: ((WN)) How did we go?

p.p: Amanda Carter: We won that tournament, which qualified us for Barcelona.

p: ((WN)) And what was Barcelona like?

p.p: Amanda Carter: Amazing. I guess because it was my first Paralympics. I hadn't long been in a wheelchair, so all of it was pretty new to me. Barcelona was done very, very well. I guess Australia wasn't expected to do very well and finished fourth, so it was a good tournament for us.

p: ((WN)) Did you play with a club as well?

p.p: Amanda Carter: I did. I played in the men's league at that point. Which was Dandenong Rangers. It had a different name back then. I can't remember what they were called back then but eventually it became the Dandenong Rangers.

p: ((WN)) The 1994 World Championships. Where was that at?

p.p: Amanda Carter: Good question. Very good question. I think it was in Stoke. 'Cause 1998 was Sydney, so I've got a feeling that it was in Stoke Mandeville in England.

p: ((WN)) Which brings us to 1996.
((WN)) Your team finished fourth.
((WN)) Lost to the Unites States in the bronze medal game in front of a crowd of 5,000.
